author: Informalia
title: Ana Duato responde a la fiscalía tras la petición de 16 años de cárcel: \"No lo entiendo y si alguien lo hace, habrá tenido suerte\"
text: Tras conocer que el fiscal anticorrupción Tomás Herranz señalaba en el juicio por el 'Caso Nummaria' que Ana Duato tuvo \"la voluntad de no declarar sus verdaderos ingresos\" y así defraudar a Hacienda, y pedía para ella 16 años de prisión, la actriz ha roto su silencio. Tranquila y sonriente, ha asegurado que ya queda poco para saber la sentencia final: \"Os pido un poquito de calma, el juicio se está acabando, de verdad y hay que tener un poquito de calma porque quedan pocos días, ya se ha escuchado el escrito de la acusación del fiscal que no hemos entendido mucho\". La actriz ha asegurado que no entiende el escrito de la fiscalía y que ahora es el turno de su abogado: \"No está muy claro pero bueno, ahora viene el escrito de defensa de mi abogado, habrá que escucharlo a él, un poquito de calma, yo creo en la justicia, hay que esperar, ahora le toca la vez a mi abogado\". En cuanto a la noticia que se ha publicado, Duato ha quitado hierro al asunto asegurando que \"eran 32, ahora son 16, no se entiende muy bien, si alguien lo ha entendido, habrá tenido suerte\". Además, ha dado \"las gracias por el interés\" y ha pedido cautela hasta que se termine el juicio. La intérprete, que se negó a pactar con la Fiscalía, ha insistido en que \"sigo en mi inocencia, os doy las gracias, pero os pido un poquito a los medios de calma, ¿vale?\".

author: Fred Horch
title: Sustainable Practice: Taking realistic steps towards sustainability as an individual
text:
In 1902, Puck magazine noted that “Things move along so rapidly nowadays that people saying: ‘It can’t be done,’ are always being interrupted by somebody doing it.” This has certainly been my experience working in the practical sustainability field for the past 30 years.
Last week, a business partner and I visited the Clay Brook high-performance home in New Hampshire that was recently built to the Phius single-family new construction standard. If you’re not familiar with Phius, it’s one of the leading “passive building” certification standards in North America. The basic idea is to use modern materials and smart techniques to build structures in any climate zone that don’t require conventional heating and air conditioning. Instead, these super-efficient buildings use sunlight, ground temperature, and natural breezes (“passive” heating and cooling) to do the heavy lifting to maintain comfortable indoor conditions all year.
Talking with the people involved with that project to understand what worked well and what could be improved so we can apply lessons learned to the commercial and residential energy-efficient construction work my company does is so much more fun for me than going to a climate rally. Those rallies were fun back in the 1990s. But nowadays, practical sustainability feels much more hopeful and personally rewarding than activist sustainability. We’re making rapid progress with practical sustainability, while progress is hard to discern in the activist arena.
The big difference between practical sustainability and activist sustainability, of course, is that practical sustainability is about what you can do. Activist sustainability is about what everyone else could do. Our planet has only one you and 8 billion “not you’s,” so it’s not unreasonable to conclude that what you do doesn’t really matter, right? Simple math proves that everyone else on the planet becoming just one-billionth more sustainable would have eight times the impact of you becoming twice as sustainable. This is why activists could rationally calculate that their time is better spent telling others what to do.
But here’s one thing to keep in mind when considering where to put your focus: Practical actions have ripple effects. We don’t have to burn fossil fuel to heat our homes — we just think we do. If a neighbor builds a new passive house or electrifies an existing house, that makes it much more likely that someone else in the neighborhood will, too.
Another thing — which many political campaigns learn to their dismay — is that it’s easy to pass a law but hard to enforce it. I love that Vermont’s ban on throwing organic waste in the trash lets everyone know what they should be doing. But studying trash samples last year showed that 46.3% of food waste is still going to landfills, despite the law. To actually compost food waste, we don’t need more laws, we need more practical ways to compost.
The rapid advance of technology — from passive houses to electric vehicles to kitchen composting appliances — opens up many more practical ways to be sustainable. For our passive house tours, we drove from Maine to New Hampshire in an all-electric Ford pickup truck, something that simply wasn’t possible to do even a few years ago. I’ve remained connected to the environmental activist community, so I understand the deep skepticism around technology as a solution to global challenges like climate change. But in today’s world we can now charge up batteries from sunlight and drive across the country!
While activist sustainability is bogged down in the muck of partisan political gridlock, practical sustainability is accelerating to achieve outcomes few thought possible. The price of solar has plummeted to make it the most affordable way to generate electricity around much of the world, and the price of batteries is following a similar projection.
We’re far from solving our environmental problems. Protests and rallies might make a difference and certainly let frustrated people blow off steam. But I hope that if we find ourselves stuck in traffic heading to a demonstration, we’ll keep a lane clear for the workers on their way to job sites to build the sustainable future we all want.
Fred Horch is principal adviser for Sustainable Practice. To learn how you can help your community achieve energy independence and other sustainable goals, visit SustainablePractice.Life and subscribe to “One Step This Week.”

author: Valley City Times-Record
title: Realtimecampaign.com Discusses the Evolution of Poster Printing in the Digital Age | User | times-online.com
text: The art of poster printing has experienced a significant transformation with the introduction of digital technology. This evolution marks a pivotal shift in visual communication, especially in the areas of online printing, and book printing and binding. Today, posters are more than mere advertising tools; they have become a medium for artistic expression, blending creativity with the advancements of technology. Traditionally, posters have been central to advertising, seen in urban landscapes, shop windows, and community boards. In the pre-digital era, they were crucial for mass communication, promoting a wide range of events, products, and services. However, the digital revolution has brought about significant changes in both the role and production methods of posters. Advancements in Digital Poster Printing One of the most notable advancements in this field is the precision and quality made possible by digital printing techniques. Modern digital printing offers a level of detail and color accuracy previously unattainable, opening new avenues for artists and designers to create intricate and visually stunning designs, as can be seen through things like the 10 Best Poster Prints for 2023 . Furthermore, the shift towards eco-friendly inks and sustainable materials reflects a growing environmental consciousness in the printing industry. Online Printing and Personalization The rise of online printing services like Printivity has revolutionized the way individuals and businesses approach poster printing. These services offer convenience and accessibility, allowing for customization and ordering from anywhere. This democratization of poster production has made it more accessible to a broader audience, altering the landscape of poster creation. The trend towards personalization and small-batch printing is another significant development. Unlike mass-produced posters of the past, today's technology enables the cost-effective production of limited editions and custom designs, catering to a growing demand for unique and personalized items. Posters in Book Printing and Promotional Materials In the realm of book printing and binding, posters have found a new role. They are increasingly used as promotional materials for book launches or as complementary art pieces in limited-edition book releases. This synergy between books and posters illustrates the cross-pollination of different media in the digital age, enhancing the overall experience for readers and art enthusiasts. Future Trends in Poster Printing Looking towards the future, the poster printing industry is poised to continue its growth and innovation. Technologies like augmented reality and interactive prints are set to redefine what posters can be and do, just have a peek at this website to get a sense of what might be done. According to realtimecampaign.com, these advancements ensure that posters will remain a vital and vibrant part of our visual culture. The transformation of poster printing in the digital age highlights a fascinating intersection of art, technology, and commerce. This evolution underscores the adaptability and enduring relevance of the poster as a medium of communication and expression. As we continue to embrace new technologies and trends, the poster remains an evolving canvas, reflecting our changing times and artistic sensibilities. Media Contact Company Name: Realtimecampaign.com Contact Person: Media Relations Email: Send Email Phone: 407-875-1833 Country: United States Website: Realtimecampaign.com

author: Pedro Castro
title: Playa artificial es un atractivo en Cabo Rojo
text: Un oasis en medio del Port Cabo Rojo donde los cruceristas se sorprendieron con las instalaciones./Foto Pedro Castro PEDERNALES.- La playa artificial “Blue Parrot” en medio del Port Cabo Rojo, fue la mayor atracción que ayer disfrutaron los cruceristas, tras su arribo en el crucero Norwegian Pearl, donde los lugareños empiezan a ver el sueño que empieza a cumplirse. Un concepto creado en 360 metros cuadrados para que las líneas de cruceros se interesen en venir a Pedernales a un puerto recién inaugurado por el presidente [Luis Abinader,](https://twitter.com/luisabinader) que a partir de su operación en el lejano sur, ha sido bautizado por el mandatario como el “sur fecundo”. En el puerto existen tiendas de regalos (Gift Shop), con ventas desde bebidas alcohólicas, perfumes, prendas preciosas, prendas de vestir y cigarros hechos a mano con precios libres de impuestos. A la playa sus precursores le llaman el Oasis donde se conjugan arena, sol y playa con gazebos, paragüitas y hamacas para que los cruceristas tomen el sol. Otros que no se quedaron en el puerto y que prefirieron el senderismo decidieron abordar un vehículo tipo “buggy” y gafas en manos y pasamontañas salieron a conocer la tierra donde el cactus y las guazábaras arropan la vegetación. A bordo llegaron 2,556 cruceristas y los organizadores estimaron que del total bajaron al puerto 2,100 equivalente a un 82%. El presidente Abinader considera que Perdernales ahora entra en un circulo virtuoso del desarrollo con la creación de empleos. Te puede interesar leer: [Llega primer crucero a puerto de Pedernales](https://elnacional.com.do/llega-primer-crucero-a-puerto-de-pedernales/) “Lo que fue un sur profundo hoy se va a convertir en un sur fecundo”, precisó el mandatario. “No se trata de un tema de votos es un tema de hacer lo correcto”, añadió. Se quejó que la oposición en vez de oponerse al proyecto que ayer inauguró debió acompañarlo. Abinader dijo que el proyecto ya es una realidad y que al final de este año tendrán operando el primer hotel y que todos los años se estarán abriendo dos o tres hoteles hasta convertir a Pedernales en una verdadera opción turística. También puede leer: [Capitán crucero llegó a Cabo Rojo es nativo de Pedernales](https://elnacional.com.do/capitan-crucero-llego-a-cabo-rojo-es-nativo-de-pedernales/) “En cinco años habrá cambiado, en diez años estará irreconocible y en 20 años toda la zona será un modelo de desarrollo económico y social”, aseguró el jefe de Estado al hablar con los periodistas. El plan El Proyecto de Desarrollo Turístico de Pedernales, Cabo Rojo está concebido para realizarse en cuatro fases, en un periodo promedio de 10 años, y una inversión estimada de 2,245 millones de dólares. Con este plan, se proyecta un millón de cruceristas para 2026, con un impacto económico en la zona de millones de dólares, 3,000 empleos directos y más de 10,000 indirectos. Esperan que al final de este 2024 iniciará la operación del primer hotel de 11 que están en proyectos. El desarrollo hotelero generará miles en empleos directos e indirectos de toda la región. Port Cabo Rojo con 400 metros de muelle, tiene capacidad para recibir dos cruceros tipo Oasis y cuenta con espacios de descanso, compras, restaurantes y bares. En las próximas etapas, se desarrollarán una feria temática, spa, bar en el mar, parque acuático y más. Está concebido como un puerto sostenible, libre de plásticos de un solo uso, que fomenta la protección de sus áreas protegidas y parques naturales. Impulso económico Llegada de cruceristas supone el impulso económico de esta provincia y la región, ya que se registra un gasto promedio de entre 80 y 100 dólares por cada uno. ITM Group, jugó un papel de primera línea en el inicio de hacer realidad un proyecto que parecía imposible y que permite que nativos de este lugar, que han emigrado, puedan regresar.
